values.description:
This aligns topic names with what's documented in #!/osrf/subt/wiki/api. That documentation should still be updated to use upper case names for `cmd_vel` messages. i.e `X1/cmd_vel` instead of `/x1/cmd_vel`.

Even though the commit message in 337a813 mentiones cmd_vel topics, this PR affects all ROS topics that were under the `/model` namespace. This PR does not modify any of the topics under ign-transport.
values.title: Rename ROS topics form /model/<robot name>/* to /<robot name>/*

summary.raw:
This aligns topic names with what's documented in #!/osrf/subt/wiki/api. That documentation should still be updated to use upper case names for `cmd_vel` messages. i.e `X1/cmd_vel` instead of `/x1/cmd_vel`.

Even though the commit message in 337a813 mentiones cmd_vel topics, this PR affects all ROS topics that were under the `/model` namespace. This PR does not modify any of the topics under ign-transport.
summary.html:
This aligns topic names with what's documented in #!/osrf/subt/wiki/api. That documentation should still be updated to use upper case names for cmd_vel messages. i.e X1/cmd_vel instead of /x1/cmd_vel.

Even though the commit message in 337a813 mentiones cmd_vel topics, this PR affects all ROS topics that were under the /model namespace. This PR does not modify any of the topics under ign-transport.

values.description:
This passes all the arguments to launch instead of just the first. This is needed to support running docker with parameters like:

```
virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName3:=X3 robotConfig3:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName4:=X4 robotConfig4:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```
values.title: Pass all args to launch

summary.raw:
This passes all the arguments to launch instead of just the first. This is needed to support running docker with parameters like:

```
virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName3:=X3 robotConfig3:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName4:=X4 robotConfig4:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```
summary.html:
This passes all the arguments to launch instead of just the first. This is needed to support running docker with parameters like:

virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName3:=X3 robotConfig3:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName4:=X4 robotConfig4:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

values.description:
Spawning of robots has been moved into the simulation launch files. This PR moves the ros robot descriptions to the simulation launch file.

The code to spawn a team has been removed from `team.ign` to make clear that a team cannot spawn their own robots. Instead a team must tell simulation what robots to spawn.
values.title: Set robot descriptions when spawning robots

summary.raw:
Spawning of robots has been moved into the simulation launch files. This PR moves the ros robot descriptions to the simulation launch file.

The code to spawn a team has been removed from `team.ign` to make clear that a team cannot spawn their own robots. Instead a team must tell simulation what robots to spawn.
summary.html:
Spawning of robots has been moved into the simulation launch files. This PR moves the ros robot descriptions to the simulation launch file.

The code to spawn a team has been removed from team.ign to make clear that a team cannot spawn their own robots. Instead a team must tell simulation what robots to spawn.

values.description:
* Expose received signal strength to the communication interface
* Update communication client with RSSI

    Fix neighbor state-reporting. Neighbors are only populated when receiving packets but the interface will also now report signal strength.


* Add simple publishing of RSSI in subt\_example\_node
* Update subt\_comms\_test to show RSSI

Fixes #51 and #64
values.title: Update neighbor reporting interface

summary.raw:
* Expose received signal strength to the communication interface
* Update communication client with RSSI

    Fix neighbor state-reporting. Neighbors are only populated when receiving packets but the interface will also now report signal strength.


* Add simple publishing of RSSI in subt\_example\_node
* Update subt\_comms\_test to show RSSI

Fixes #51 and #64
summary.html:
• Expose received signal strength to the communication interface

  • Update communication client with RSSI

    Fix neighbor state-reporting. Neighbors are only populated when receiving packets but the interface will also now report signal strength.

  • Add simple publishing of RSSI in subt_example_node

  • Update subt_comms_test to show RSSI

Fixes #51 and #64

values.description:
Add sonar sensors pointing up and down on the X4 sensor configuration #2. Sonar sensors are common on real UAV systems. Unsure how to bridge ign to ros msgs in for the ignition version of this sensor configuration.

Add dependency:

`sudo apt install ros-melodic-hector-sensors-description`

We are certainly open to all teams using this set of sensors.  The sonars could potentially be added to all X4 configurations.
values.title: Add sonar sensor to X4 Configuration #2

summary.raw:
Add sonar sensors pointing up and down on the X4 sensor configuration #2. Sonar sensors are common on real UAV systems. Unsure how to bridge ign to ros msgs in for the ignition version of this sensor configuration.

Add dependency:

`sudo apt install ros-melodic-hector-sensors-description`

We are certainly open to all teams using this set of sensors.  The sonars could potentially be added to all X4 configurations.
summary.html:
Add sonar sensors pointing up and down on the X4 sensor configuration #2. Sonar sensors are common on real UAV systems. Unsure how to bridge ign to ros msgs in for the ignition version of this sensor configuration.

Add dependency:

sudo apt install ros-melodic-hector-sensors-description

We are certainly open to all teams using this set of sensors. The sonars could potentially be added to all X4 configurations.

values.description:
I have created a [testing branch](#!/osrf/subt/branch/default_topics_testing) that uses models uploaded to my fuel account. Currently only X1 configurations have been uploaded. I'll continue to upload the rest.

Example test (using the default_topics_testing branch)
```
ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1_C1 robotName2:=X1_C2 robotName3:=X1_C3 robotName4:=X1_C4 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotConfig2:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_2 robotConfig3:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_3 robotConfig4:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_4
```
On the ROS side topic names should conform to the pattern specified in the [API Docs](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api). `frame_id`s follow the pattern `<ROBOT_NAME>/base_link/<sensor name>`

**Depends on:**

 * [ign-gazebo #364]( https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/364)
*  [ign-sensors #74](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/74)
values.title: Modify topic remaps to use sensor default topics

On the ROS side topic names should conform to the pattern specified in the [API Docs](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api). `frame_id`s follow the pattern `<ROBOT_NAME>/base_link/<sensor name>`

**Depends on:**

 * [ign-gazebo #364]( https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/364)
*  [ign-sensors #74](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/74)

ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1_C1 robotName2:=X1_C2 robotName3:=X1_C3 robotName4:=X1_C4 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotConfig2:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_2 robotConfig3:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_3 robotConfig4:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_4

On the ROS side topic names should conform to the pattern specified in the API Docs. frame_ids follow the pattern <ROBOT_NAME>/base_link/<sensor name>

values.description:
Testing with virtual_stix:

~~~
ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
~~~

Calling the service with the default branch fails:

~~~
$ rosservice call /subt/pose_from_artifact_origin "robot_name:
  data: 'X1'" 
ERROR: service [/subt/pose_from_artifact_origin] responded with an error:
~~~

The simulator displays the following console message:

~~~
[Err] [GameLogicPlugin.cc:658] [GameLogicPlugin]: Unable to find the staging area [BaseStation]. Ignoring PoseFromArtifact request
~~~

If you only fix the base station name, then you see the following console message:

~~~
[Err] [GameLogicPlugin.cc:669] [GameLogicPlugin]: Robot [X1] is too far from the staging area. Ignoring PoseFromArtifact request
~~~

With both of these changes, the service works:

~~~
$ rosservice call /subt/pose_from_artifact_origin "robot_name:
  data: 'X1'" 
pose: 
  header: 
    seq: 0
    stamp: 
      secs: 16
      nsecs: 993000000
    frame_id: "base_station"
  pose: 
    position: 
      x: 4.00014348786
      y: 3.99999559842
      z: 0.131239979914
    orientation: 
      x: 1.66305568829e-05
      y: 4.52010575779e-05
      z: 6.6992448231e-10
      w: 0.99999999884
success: True
~~~
values.title: Fix pose_from_artifact_origin service

summary.raw:
Testing with virtual_stix:

~~~
ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
~~~

Calling the service with the default branch fails:

~~~
$ rosservice call /subt/pose_from_artifact_origin "robot_name:
  data: 'X1'" 
ERROR: service [/subt/pose_from_artifact_origin] responded with an error:
~~~

The simulator displays the following console message:

~~~
[Err] [GameLogicPlugin.cc:658] [GameLogicPlugin]: Unable to find the staging area [BaseStation]. Ignoring PoseFromArtifact request
~~~

If you only fix the base station name, then you see the following console message:

~~~
[Err] [GameLogicPlugin.cc:669] [GameLogicPlugin]: Robot [X1] is too far from the staging area. Ignoring PoseFromArtifact request
~~~

With both of these changes, the service works:

~~~
$ rosservice call /subt/pose_from_artifact_origin "robot_name:
  data: 'X1'" 
pose: 
  header: 
    seq: 0
    stamp: 
      secs: 16
      nsecs: 993000000
    frame_id: "base_station"
  pose: 
    position: 
      x: 4.00014348786
      y: 3.99999559842
      z: 0.131239979914
    orientation: 
      x: 1.66305568829e-05
      y: 4.52010575779e-05
      z: 6.6992448231e-10
      w: 0.99999999884
success: True
~~~
summary.html:
Testing with virtual_stix:

ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

Calling the service with the default branch fails:

$ rosservice call /subt/pose_from_artifact_origin "robot_name:
  data: 'X1'" 
ERROR: service [/subt/pose_from_artifact_origin] responded with an error:

The simulator displays the following console message:

[Err] [GameLogicPlugin.cc:658] [GameLogicPlugin]: Unable to find the staging area [BaseStation]. Ignoring PoseFromArtifact request

If you only fix the base station name, then you see the following console message:

[Err] [GameLogicPlugin.cc:669] [GameLogicPlugin]: Robot [X1] is too far from the staging area. Ignoring PoseFromArtifact request

With both of these changes, the service works:

$ rosservice call /subt/pose_from_artifact_origin "robot_name:
  data: 'X1'" 
pose: 
  header: 
    seq: 0
    stamp: 
      secs: 16
      nsecs: 993000000
    frame_id: "base_station"
  pose: 
    position: 
      x: 4.00014348786
      y: 3.99999559842
      z: 0.131239979914
    orientation: 
      x: 1.66305568829e-05
      y: 4.52010575779e-05
      z: 6.6992448231e-10
      w: 0.99999999884
success: True


Levels are currently disabled.

values.description:
This is meant to address issue #79 and issue #91. You will also need: https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/369/fix-odometry-frame-names/diff

The end result in TF is: `X1/odom` --> `X1` --> `X1/base_link`. There is an extra `X1` frame in there, but this solution was the easiest to make.
values.title: Fix odom broadcasting

summary.raw:
This is meant to address issue #79 and issue #91. You will also need: https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/369/fix-odometry-frame-names/diff

The end result in TF is: `X1/odom` --> `X1` --> `X1/base_link`. There is an extra `X1` frame in there, but this solution was the easiest to make.
summary.html:
This is meant to address issue #79 and issue #91. You will also need: https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/369/fix-odometry-frame-names/diff

The end result in TF is: X1/odom --> X1 --> X1/base_link. There is an extra X1 frame in there, but this solution was the easiest to make.

values.description:
The `subt_gazebo` package on the gazebo9 branch has a test of the scoring system:

* #!/osrf/subt/src/gazebo9/subt_gazebo/test/score.cc

This ports that test to the `subt_ign` package, though I haven't figured out how to bring up the simulated world as part of the test. I've managed to make it work by bringing up the `virtual_stix` environment manually and then manually running the test using the following commands:

~~~
ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign \
  robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 \
  robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
~~~

~~~
# after world has loaded, start scoring:
rosservice call /subt/start "data: true"
# then manually run the test built in colcon workspace at path WS_PATH
${WS_PATH}/build/subt_ign/devel/lib/subt_ign/test_score
~~~
values.title: Port scoring test to subt_ign

summary.raw:
The `subt_gazebo` package on the gazebo9 branch has a test of the scoring system:

* #!/osrf/subt/src/gazebo9/subt_gazebo/test/score.cc

This ports that test to the `subt_ign` package, though I haven't figured out how to bring up the simulated world as part of the test. I've managed to make it work by bringing up the `virtual_stix` environment manually and then manually running the test using the following commands:

~~~
ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign \
  robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 \
  robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
~~~

~~~
# after world has loaded, start scoring:
rosservice call /subt/start "data: true"
# then manually run the test built in colcon workspace at path WS_PATH
${WS_PATH}/build/subt_ign/devel/lib/subt_ign/test_score
~~~
summary.html:
The subt_gazebo package on the gazebo9 branch has a test of the scoring system:

  • #!/osrf/subt/src/gazebo9/subt_gazebo/test/score.cc

This ports that test to the subt_ign package, though I haven't figured out how to bring up the simulated world as part of the test. I've managed to make it work by bringing up the virtual_stix environment manually and then manually running the test using the following commands:

ign launch -v 4 virtual_stix.ign \
  robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 \
  robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

# after world has loaded, start scoring:
rosservice call /subt/start "data: true"
# then manually run the test built in colcon workspace at path WS_PATH
${WS_PATH}/build/subt_ign/devel/lib/subt_ign/test_score

values.description: Fix issue #94
values.title: Fix odom frames for x3 and x4

summary.raw: Fix issue #94
summary.html: Fix issue #94

values.description:
Fixes issue #92

[Robot configurations](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/robots) with stereo cameras \(\*\_CONFIG\_5\) now output camera image data to these topics, i.e.

* /<robot\_name>/front/left/image\_raw
* /<robot\_name>/front/left/camera\_info
* /<robot\_name>/front/right/image\_raw
* /<robot\_name>/front/right/camera\_info

I also had to update `X2 Config 5` model's camera sensor name to be consistent with other models so that its camera data can be piped properly. The new model has been uploaded onto fuel so you'll need to remove the `X2 Config 5` directory in fuel cache: `~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/X2 Config 5`

I also made changes to prevent piping 2d laser scan data if the robot is using 3d lidar.
values.title: Fix stereo cam and 3d lidar sensor data topics

summary.raw:
Fixes issue #92

[Robot configurations](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/robots) with stereo cameras \(\*\_CONFIG\_5\) now output camera image data to these topics, i.e.

* /<robot\_name>/front/left/image\_raw
* /<robot\_name>/front/left/camera\_info
* /<robot\_name>/front/right/image\_raw
* /<robot\_name>/front/right/camera\_info

I also had to update `X2 Config 5` model's camera sensor name to be consistent with other models so that its camera data can be piped properly. The new model has been uploaded onto fuel so you'll need to remove the `X2 Config 5` directory in fuel cache: `~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/X2 Config 5`

I also made changes to prevent piping 2d laser scan data if the robot is using 3d lidar.
summary.html:
Fixes issue #92

Robot configurations with stereo cameras (*_CONFIG_5) now output camera image data to these topics, i.e.

  • /<robot_name>/front/left/image_raw
  • /<robot_name>/front/left/camera_info
  • /<robot_name>/front/right/image_raw
  • /<robot_name>/front/right/camera_info

I also had to update X2 Config 5 model's camera sensor name to be consistent with other models so that its camera data can be piped properly. The new model has been uploaded onto fuel so you'll need to remove the X2 Config 5 directory in fuel cache: ~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/X2 Config 5

I also made changes to prevent piping 2d laser scan data if the robot is using 3d lidar.

values.description:
`.dot` topology files and gazebo9 `.world` files for tunnel circuit practice worlds 01-03 for DAT generation.

Nothing new here but memo for those not aware:

* Slight change in `.tsv` files: `base_station,0,0` string is needed for DOT topology generation. It has been added to the corresponding cells in 01 and 03. \(02 already had it.\)
* Slight change in `.sdf` files: base station needs to use vertex 0 as a clean way for DAT generation, so all tiles now start at 1 instead of 0. This results in diffs in the SDF files - all tile numbers are shifted by \+1.
values.title: DOT topology files for tunnel circuit practice 01-03

summary.raw:
`.dot` topology files and gazebo9 `.world` files for tunnel circuit practice worlds 01-03 for DAT generation.

Nothing new here but memo for those not aware:

* Slight change in `.tsv` files: `base_station,0,0` string is needed for DOT topology generation. It has been added to the corresponding cells in 01 and 03. \(02 already had it.\)
* Slight change in `.sdf` files: base station needs to use vertex 0 as a clean way for DAT generation, so all tiles now start at 1 instead of 0. This results in diffs in the SDF files - all tile numbers are shifted by \+1.
summary.html:
.dot topology files and gazebo9 .world files for tunnel circuit practice worlds 01-03 for DAT generation.

Nothing new here but memo for those not aware:

  • Slight change in .tsv files: base_station,0,0 string is needed for DOT topology generation. It has been added to the corresponding cells in 01 and 03. (02 already had it.)
  • Slight change in .sdf files: base station needs to use vertex 0 as a clean way for DAT generation, so all tiles now start at 1 instead of 0. This results in diffs in the SDF files - all tile numbers are shifted by +1.

values.description: The drones don't lift off when using teleop with the logitech joystick without increasing the `scale_vertical*` parameters. I've copied them from the ps3 config, and the drones can fly now.
values.title: logitech_config.yaml: copy vertical scale from ps3 config

summary.raw: The drones don't lift off when using teleop with the logitech joystick without increasing the `scale_vertical*` parameters. I've copied them from the ps3 config, and the drones can fly now.
summary.html: The drones don't lift off when using teleop with the logitech joystick without increasing the scale_vertical* parameters. I've copied them from the ps3 config, and the drones can fly now.

Affects X3 config 3, X3 config 4, and X4 config 2

values.description: Cloudsim needs to know when a simulation run has been started by a user. This PR relays the start signal over ignition-transport, which can be accessed by cloudsim.

values.description:
The inertial values in the X3 UAVs seem to cause instability when flying the X3. 

**Old**

![old_inertia_opt.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2729534006-old_inertia_opt.gif)

**New**

![new_inertia_opt.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3000983001-new_inertia_opt.gif)

The new values will be updated in fuel once this PR is merged.

I also found that the inertia values in iris.yaml (X3) and neo11.yaml (X4) files in the `rotors_gazebo` package do not correspond to the inertias in the corresponding SDF models. So I've made local copies of the yaml files and updated them to match the SDF models. I didn't a significant difference with the performance of X4 though.

# Testing

First update the inertia of your local X3 Config 1 in ` ~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/X3 UAV Config 1/3` with this patch
```
diff -u old/model.sdf new/model.sdf
--- old/model.sdf	2019-07-11 17:07:27.227882579 -0500
+++ new/model.sdf	2019-07-11 17:34:43.739838647 -0500
@@ -7,12 +7,12 @@
                 <pose frame="">0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
                 <mass>1.5</mass>
                 <inertia>
-                    <ixx>0.0347563</ixx>
+                    <ixx>0.025</ixx>
                     <ixy>0</ixy>
                     <ixz>0</ixz>
-                    <iyy>0.07</iyy>
+                    <iyy>0.009</iyy>
                     <iyz>0</iyz>
-                    <izz>0.0977</izz>
+                    <izz>0.033</izz>
                 </inertia>
             </inertial>
             <collision name="base_link_inertia_collision">
```
or manually update them so that `xx = 0.0254, yy = 0.0092, zz = 0.0337`.

I've created a branch [uav_inertia_change_test](#!/osrf/subt/branch/uav_inertia_change_test) that uses ground truth measurements and the Lee position controller. Once the branch is installed, run

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=X3 robotConfig1:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X4 robotConfig2:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```

in another terminal,

```
rostopic pub /X3/command/pose geometry_msgs/PoseStamped "header:
  seq: 0
  stamp:
    secs: 10
    nsecs: 0
  frame_id: ''
pose:
  position:
    x: 4.0
    y: 5.0
    z: 5.0
  orientation:
    x: 0.0
    y: 0.0
    z: 0.0
    w: 1.0"
```

and

```
rostopic pub /X4/command/pose geometry_msgs/PoseStamped "header:
  seq: 0
  stamp:
    secs: 10
    nsecs: 0
  frame_id: ''
pose:
  position:
    x: 4.0
    y: 3.0
    z: 5.0
  orientation:
    x: 0.0
    y: 0.0
    z: 0.0
    w: 1.0"
```

To test the old behavior, revert the patch in `X3 Config 1` and change `x3_control/launch/control.launch` to use 
```
      <rosparam command="load" file="$(find rotors_gazebo)/resource/iris.yaml" />
```
instead of
```
      <rosparam command="load" file="$(find x3_control)/resource/iris.yaml" />
```
values.title: Update X3 MOI and make sure iris.yaml and neo11.yaml match the MOI in corresponding SDF models

summary.raw:
The inertial values in the X3 UAVs seem to cause instability when flying the X3. 

**Old**

![old_inertia_opt.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2729534006-old_inertia_opt.gif)

**New**

![new_inertia_opt.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3000983001-new_inertia_opt.gif)

The new values will be updated in fuel once this PR is merged.

I also found that the inertia values in iris.yaml (X3) and neo11.yaml (X4) files in the `rotors_gazebo` package do not correspond to the inertias in the corresponding SDF models. So I've made local copies of the yaml files and updated them to match the SDF models. I didn't a significant difference with the performance of X4 though.

# Testing

First update the inertia of your local X3 Config 1 in ` ~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/X3 UAV Config 1/3` with this patch
```

--- old/model.sdf	2019-07-11 17:07:27.227882579 -0500
+++ new/model.sdf	2019-07-11 17:34:43.739838647 -0500
@@ -7,12 +7,12 @@
                 <pose frame="">0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
                 <mass>1.5</mass>
                 <inertia>
-                    <ixx>0.0347563</ixx>
+                    <ixx>0.025</ixx>
                     <ixy>0</ixy>
                     <ixz>0</ixz>
-                    <iyy>0.07</iyy>
+                    <iyy>0.009</iyy>
                     <iyz>0</iyz>
-                    <izz>0.0977</izz>
+                    <izz>0.033</izz>
                 </inertia>
             </inertial>
             <collision name="base_link_inertia_collision">
```
or manually update them so that `xx = 0.0254, yy = 0.0092, zz = 0.0337`.

I've created a branch [uav_inertia_change_test](#!/osrf/subt/branch/uav_inertia_change_test) that uses ground truth measurements and the Lee position controller. Once the branch is installed, run

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=X3 robotConfig1:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X4 robotConfig2:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```

in another terminal,

```
rostopic pub /X3/command/pose geometry_msgs/PoseStamped "header:
  seq: 0
  stamp:
    secs: 10
    nsecs: 0
  frame_id: ''
pose:
  position:
    x: 4.0
    y: 5.0
    z: 5.0
  orientation:
    x: 0.0
    y: 0.0
    z: 0.0
    w: 1.0"
```

and

```
rostopic pub /X4/command/pose geometry_msgs/PoseStamped "header:
  seq: 0
  stamp:
    secs: 10
    nsecs: 0
  frame_id: ''
pose:
  position:
    x: 4.0
    y: 3.0
    z: 5.0
  orientation:
    x: 0.0
    y: 0.0
    z: 0.0
    w: 1.0"
```

To test the old behavior, revert the patch in `X3 Config 1` and change `x3_control/launch/control.launch` to use 
```
      <rosparam command="load" file="$(find rotors_gazebo)/resource/iris.yaml" />
```
instead of
```
      <rosparam command="load" file="$(find x3_control)/resource/iris.yaml" />
```

New

The new values will be updated in fuel once this PR is merged.

I also found that the inertia values in iris.yaml (X3) and neo11.yaml (X4) files in the rotors_gazebo package do not correspond to the inertias in the corresponding SDF models. So I've made local copies of the yaml files and updated them to match the SDF models. I didn't a significant difference with the performance of X4 though.

Testing

@@ -7,12 +7,12 @@

                 <mass>1.5</mass>
                 <inertia>
-                    <ixx>0.0347563</ixx>
+                    <ixx>0.025</ixx>
                     <ixy>0</ixy>

-                    <izz>0.0977</izz>
+                    <izz>0.033</izz>
                 </inertia>
             </inertial>

or manually update them so that xx = 0.0254, yy = 0.0092, zz = 0.0337.

I've created a branch uav_inertia_change_test that uses ground truth measurements and the Lee position controller. Once the branch is installed, run

ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=X3 robotConfig1:=X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X4 robotConfig2:=X4_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

values.description:
We are isolating ROS to be present only on a competitor's EC2 instance. In order to achieve this, we have to remove ROS from the simulation side of things.

This PR is a small step in that direction.
values.title: Remove ROS from CommsBroker

summary.raw:
We are isolating ROS to be present only on a competitor's EC2 instance. In order to achieve this, we have to remove ROS from the simulation side of things.

This PR is a small step in that direction.
summary.html:
We are isolating ROS to be present only on a competitor's EC2 instance. In order to achieve this, we have to remove ROS from the simulation side of things.

This PR is a small step in that direction.

values.description: In the same vein as pull request #196, this PR removes ROS from the GameLogicPlugin. There is now a `SubtRosRelay` node that is launched to bridge Ignition Transport and ROS.
values.title: Remove ros from GameLogicPlugin

summary.raw: In the same vein as pull request #196, this PR removes ROS from the GameLogicPlugin. There is now a `SubtRosRelay` node that is launched to bridge Ignition Transport and ROS.
summary.html: In the same vein as pull request #196, this PR removes ROS from the GameLogicPlugin. There is now a SubtRosRelay node that is launched to bridge Ignition Transport and ROS.

values.description:
Please review pull request #196 and pull request #197 first. Merging in those two pull requests will make this PR much easier to review.

The major addition to this PR is the inclusion of two new Dockerfiles:
1. `cloudsim_sim`: This dockerfile will be used by Cloudsim to run simulation.
2. `cloudsim_bridge`: This dockerfile will be use by Cloudsim to run a ROS master and the ROS1-Ign bridge.

More information about this architecture is being added to: #!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/cloudsim
values.title: Ros relay

2. `cloudsim_bridge`: This dockerfile will be use by Cloudsim to run a ROS master and the ROS1-Ign bridge.

More information about this architecture is being added to: #!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/cloudsim
